# Gasses Gasses are a critical part of the station's operation. You may know them as the stuff you breathe, but they are also used in many other ways.
Gasses have certain properties that make them useful for different tasks. Atmospherics can also synthesize exotic gasses from other gasses, which can be used for special purposes.

## Oxygen
A common gas, used by most species on the station to breathe.
Oxygen is an oxidizer, which means it supports combustion. This makes it both useful when fusing gasses in a burn chamber, and dangerous when mixed with flammable gasses.
## Nitrogen
An inert gas, used in part with oxygen to create a breathable atmosphere.
Nitrogen is very stable and comprises most of a standard breathable atmosphere.
Some species, like Slimes breathe nitrogen, with Vox strictly requiring nitrogen to breathe.
## Air Mix
A mixture of gasses that is breathable to most species on the station. It consists of 21% Oxygen and 79% Nitrogen.
## Carbon Dioxide
A waste gas produced by most species on the station. A common byproduct of combustion.
Despite seeming useless, some departments use it in their line of work.
## Water Vapor
A common gas, produced by the burning of plasma and other processes.
Water vapor has a good specific heat capacity compared to other gasses, making it useful for moving heat around.
## Ammonia
A gas produced by the decomposition of bodies.
Can be condensed to create ammonia, which can be used to make space cleaner.
## Plasma
A highly flammable gas that is used in many processes on the station.
Engineering uses this gas to generate power and create exotic gasses.
Burning it generates a lot of heat, as well as gas byproducts such as carbon dioxide, water vapor, and tritium, depending on the efficiency of the burn.
Plasma gas also has a good specific heat capacity, making it useful for moving heat around.
## Tritium
Tritium is a clear, green gas that is highly flammable, radioactive, and combusts when in contact with oxygen, making it very helpful when running the [color=#a4885c]TEG[/color].
It can be made by burning 1% Plasma and 96% or more Oxygen in the Burn Chamber (Ideal ratio is rough 3% Plasma to 97% Oxygen when injected into an ongoing burn chamber). You can extract this gas through scrubbers to prevent further combustion in pipes.
##Pluoxium Pluoxium is a non-reactive Oxygen substitute that delivers eight times as much O2 to the bloodstream, with as little 3 kPa minimum pressure required for internals. It can be made by combining 66% Carbon Dioxide, 33% Oxygen, 1% Tritium together in an exothermic reaction between 50 and 273 kelvin. This reaction will also produce Hydogen as a byproduct. Furthermore, Pluoxium is also created by the Supermatter, when Oxygen and CO2 are present.
## Frezon
A highly sought after gas, due to the difficulty in creating it and its many properties.
It has an extremely high specific heat capacity, making it excellent for moving large amounts of heat around.
Frezon can combine in the air with Nitrogen to create Nitrous Oxide, alongside cooling down the air significantly to below freezing temperatures.
If you're looking to create this gas yourself, here's what you need to know: - The reaction requires 90% Oxygen, 8% Nitrogen, and 2% Tritium at or below 73.15 Kelvin. - Nitrogen is required as a catalyst for the reaction. The amount of Nitrogen consumed is dependent on the efficiency of the reaction. - The closer to 73.15 Kelvin, the more frezon is produced, and the less Nitrogen is consumed.
Remember, atmospherics is all about experimentation and process optimization. Try it until you get it right!
## Nitrous Oxide
A recreational and waste gas, produced by slimes and the combination of frezon and nitrogen.
##BZ BZ gas is a potent hallucinogenic, as well as a sleeping agent for slimes. It is toxic to breathe and causes respiratory irritation and coughing. BZ sees frequent use as an ingredient in more complex gas reactions. It can be made by combining 33% Nitrous Oxide and 66% Plasma in an exothermic reaction. The reaction becomes less efficient if the Plasma content is greater than 3 times the Nitrous Oxide Content. The reaction is fastest outside of pipes and in low pressure enviroments.
##Healium Healium is a red gas, formed in cold environments, which acts as a strong sleeping agent, while healing burns, bruises, and toxin damage. Excessive use will lead to inebriation. It can be made by combining 92% Frezon and 8% BZ in an exothermic reaction.
##Halon Halon suppresses fires by consuming oxygen, at a ratio of 20 moles Oxygen per 1 mole Halon, above 343.15 Kelvin in an endothermic reaction, producing Carbon Dioxide. It's made in an extremely exothermic reaction by electrolyzing BZ, yielding 2 moles halon and 0.2 moles oxygen per mole BZ. Use cautiously to avoid Oxygen depletion.
##Nitrium Nitrium is a gaseous stimulant that when inhaled can enhance speed and endurance. At lower concentrations Nitrium will increase your top running speed while healthy and unimpaired. Additionally, at slightly higher concentrations, breathing Nitrium will prevent drowsiness. At high concentrations breathing it will begin to shut down a person's lungs, causing asphyxiation. It can be made by combining 47.5% Nitrogen, 47.5% Tritium, and 5% BZ at or above 1,500 Kelvin. With higher tempature giving greater efficiency.
Nitrium degrades into nitrogen and hydrogen on contact with room temperature oxygen. This reaction can produce a good deal of heat, making the station uncomfortably warm in the event of a leak.
##Hydrogen Hydrogen is a highly flammable but non-toxic gas that burns similarly to tritium, making it useful as a fuel source. It is produced by electrolyzing Water Vapor with an electrolyzer machine to produce Hydrogen and Oxygen.
When mixed with BZ at temperatures below 273 Kelvin and pressures above 10 MPa, Hydrogen can form metal hydrogen, a rare material. Handle Hydrogen carefully to prevent fires or explosions, and store canisters securely.
##Proto-Nitrate Proto-Nitrate is a highly reactive, non-toxic gas. Combine 1 mole Hydrogen with 0.1 moles Pluoxium to yield 1.1 moles Proto-Nitrate exothermically, between 5,000 and 10,000 Kelvin. It reacts with Hydrogen or Tritium to adjust Proto-Nitrate or produce Hydrogen, and with BZ at 260-280K to yield Nitrogen, Helium, and Plasma. Handle carefully to avoid leaks.
##Helium Helium is an inert, invisible gas produced via the decay of BZ. This decay can be caused by exposing BZ and Proto Nitrate together at just under room temperature (260-280 Kelvin). It has minimal use in atmospherics, so scrub it to avoid diluting other gases.
##Hyper-Noblium Hyper-Noblium is a rare gas known for its high thermal capacity and ability to halt all reactions while above 20 kelvin. It is the best possible coolant in the sector, but is extremely difficult to produce. Exposing 10 moles Nitrogen and 5 Moles Tritium to temperatures below 15 Kelvin will produce 1 mole of Hyper-Noblium. The reaction is also strongly exothermic, so your production rate will depend on how much cooling you can provide to the reaction.
Adding large amounts of BZ to the reaction chamber is almost required to create large amounts of Hyper-Noblium. BZ will reduce the amount of Tritium consumed significantly, as well as significantly reduce the exothermic nature of the reaction.
##Anti-Noblium Anti-Noblium is a rare gas with niche uses, produced by electrolyzing Hyper-Noblium below 150 Kelvin, yielding 0.5 moles Anti-Noblium per mole Hyper-Noblium. Store carefully to preserve Hyper-Noblium stocks for other reactions.
Hyper-Noblium's special property to prevent reactions does not apply to the creation of Anti-Noblium, the same is true for all other reactions that include the electrolyzer.
##Zauker Zauker is a deadly gas if inhaled. Its produced by combining 0.2 moles Hyper-Noblium with 1 mole Nitrium between 50,000 and 75,000 Kelvin to yield 1 mole Zauker exothermically. It is a difficult gas to make due to Hyper-Noblium's ability to halt reactions, requiring extreme control of the reaction chamber to even react.
It decomposes with Nitrogen into 0.3 moles Oxygen and 0.7 moles Nitrogen per mole Zauker, also exothermic and inhibited similarly. Store securely to prevent leaks.
